content: The child nutrition programs, overseen by the USDA-FNS, include the NSLP, SBP, Fresh Fruit and Vegetable Program, Special Milk Program, Child and Adult Care Food Program, and Summer Food Service Program. These programs provide meals and snacks to children in various institutional settings. The programs were last reauthorized by the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010. The child nutrition programs, including NSLP and SBP, were last reauthorized by the Healthy, Hunger-Free Kids Act of 2010. Some authorities expired in 2015, but program operations continued with annual appropriations. Lawmakers in the 114th Congress began but did not complete child nutrition reauthorization. Russell National School Lunch Act and the Child Nutrition Act. Legislation (S. 3136 and H.R. 5003) for reauthorization died at the end of the 114th Congress. The implementation of the HHFKA and issues raised during farm bill negotiations may be relevant for future reauthorization efforts or policymaking opportunities, particularly regarding the nutritional quality and sourcing of foods in schools. The report highlights key issues for Congress in future child nutrition reauthorization efforts, including the nutritional quality of foods, access to meals, and implementation of the Community Eligibility Provision. Stakeholders involved in these issues include school food authorities, advocacy organizations, and food industry groups. This report provides an overview of current issues in child nutrition programs, including concerns raised by Congress and stakeholders. It references CRS reports for more detailed information on specific issues and legislative proposals in the 114th and 115th Congresses.
